comment.author: 100199010@N05
comment._content: He died 1 Jul 1916 at the age of 28 and was from Motherwell, Lanarkshire, born about 1888.  He is buried at Serre Road Cemetery No. 1, Puisieux, Departement du Pas-de-Calais, Nord-Pas-de-Calais, France.  He was born 29th July 1888 to William Hamilton Arnott, a steel works clerk, and his wife Janet MacGowan who were married 20 September 1887 in Stirling.  They lived on Hamilton Street in Motherwell.

comment.author: 79891751@N08
comment._content: When the CWGC records were collected the Hamiltons were living at 55 West Regent Street, Glasgow.

comment._content: He also had a brother Harry who served in the Royal Scots Fusiliers and he survived the war

comment.author: 79891751@N08
comment._content: In 1911 George was living with his parents at Glencairn, Orchard Street, Motherwell. At this time his father described himself as an Iron Merchant (Employer). George was described as age 22, a clerk (worker) in the bridge building industry. George was the eldest child living with the family in 1911: he had a younger brother, Harry M, age 21, a draughtsman in an electrical firm, and two younger sisters, Madge M, age 19, a typist for an Iron Merchant, and Janetta MM, age 9, a schoolgirl.

comment.author: 13706945@N00
comment._content: The Scottish War Memorials Project (member jrah60) links the CWGC database entry for the George Arnott featured here (i.e., Service No: 26194) with the one commemorated on the Pollokshields Church of Scotland memorial. Without further information, however, it is difficult to accept the identification as being definitive, but the page does include some images of the memorial and the church's book of remembrance.

comment.author: 79891751@N08
comment._content: He was awarded the Victory Medal and the British Medal but not the Star, which means that he did not enter a war zone until after 31 Dec 1915.
